content.text: On Fig. 1.1, measure the distance \(d\), from the bottom of the clamp to the bottom of the bob
Fig. 1.1 is drawn \(1 / 10^{\text{th}}\) actual size. Calculate the actual distance \(D\) from the bottom of the clamp to the bottom of the bob
Explain briefly how to use a set-square to avoid a parallax (line-of-sight) error when measuring the length of this pendulum. You may draw a diagram
Write down the time \(t\) shown in Fig. 1.2
Calculate the period \(T_{1}\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation
The student displaces the bob slightly and releases it so that it swings. She measures the time \(t\) for 20 complete oscillations. The time \(t\) is shown on the stopwatch in Fig. 1.2

The student repeats the procedure using another pendulum as shown in Fig. 1.3. This has a long, thin pendulum bob. The distance \(D\) from the bottom of the clamp to the bottom of the pendulum bob is the same as for the first pendulum
She determines the period \(T_{2}\) of this pendulum

In this experiment, both pendulum bobs have the same mass. A student suggests that since both pendulums have the same overall length \(D\) and mass, the periods \(T_{1}\) and \(T_{2}\) should be equal. State whether the results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to the results
statement
justification

The period \(T\) of a pendulum can be determined by measuring the time \(t\) for 20 complete oscillations and then calculating the period. Some students are asked to explain the reason for this method being more accurate than measuring the time taken for a single oscillation
Tick the box next to the sentence that gives the best explanation
The method eliminates errors from the measurements
The method is more accurate because the experiment is repeated
The method includes more readings so there is less chance for errors
The method reduces the effect of errors when starting and stopping the stopwatch
A student plans to carry out more pendulum experiments. He considers possible variables and precautions to improve accuracy
In the following list, mark the possible variables with the letter \(\mathbf{V}\) and the precautions with the letter \(\mathbf{P}\)
amplitude of swing
length of pendulum
mass of pendulum bob
shape of pendulum bob
use of a reference point to aid counting
viewing the rule at right-angles when measuring the length
A student is comparing the oscillations of two pendulums. Fig. 1.1 shows the first pendulum
The thermometer in Fig. 2.1 shows room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
Fig. 2.1
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)   .........  \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
The student pours \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into a beaker
He measures the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the hot water
\(\theta_{\mathrm{H}} =\)   .........  \(86^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
He adds \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water to the beaker. He stirs the water briefly
He measures the new temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) of the water in the beaker
\(\theta_{\mathrm{M}} =\)   .........  \(52^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Calculate the temperature fall \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} = (\theta_{\mathrm{H}} - \theta_{\mathrm{M}})\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} =\)
He repeats the procedure in **(b)** using \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water and \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water
\(\theta_{\mathrm{H}} =\)   .........  \(84^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{M}} =\)   .........  \(54^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Calculate the temperature fall \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} = (\theta_{\mathrm{H}} - \theta_{\mathrm{M}})\)
Suggest **one** reason for stirring the water before reading \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\)
A student states that the temperature fall \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) should be the same each time because the proportions of hot and cold water are the same
Suggest **one** reason why \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) could be significantly different in **(b)** and **(c)**
Suggest an improvement to the apparatus to make it more likely that \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) would be the same each time
Suggest a condition, not included in your answer to (f), that you would control to make it more likely that \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) would be the same each time

The student uses a measuring cylinder to measure the volume of water he uses. Draw a measuring cylinder about half-full of water. Show clearly on your diagram the line-of-sight required for obtaining a correct reading for the volume of water
A student is investigating the cooling of water
â€¢ The student places the screen about \(100\mathrm{cm}\) from the illuminated object
â€¢ She places the lens between the object and the screen so that the centre of the lens is at a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the object
â€¢ She adjusts the position of the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen
â€¢ She measures the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen
â€¢ She repeats the procedure using values for \(u\) of \(22.0 \text{cm}, 25.0 \text{cm}, 30.0 \text{cm}\) and \(35.0 \text{cm}\)
â€¢ The readings are shown in Table 3.1
â€¢ Mark, with a cross, the point on the graph grid where \(u = 25.0 \text{cm}\) and \(v = 25.0 \text{cm}\)
â€¢ Mark with a cross, the point on the graph grid where \(u = 35.0 \text{cm}\) and \(v = 35.0 \text{cm}\)
â€¢ Join these two points with a straight line
â€¢ Record \(u_{1}\), the value of \(u\) at the point where the straight line crosses your graph line
â€¢ Record \(v_{1}\), the value of \(v\) at the point where the straight line crosses your graph line
Calculate the focal length \(f\) of the lens using the equation \(f = \frac{(u_1 + v_1)}{4}\)
Suggest two differences that you would expect to see between the appearance of the illuminated object and the image on the screen
Suggest two precautions that you would take in order to obtain reliable readings in this experiment
A student is determining the focal length \(f\) of a lens
Fig. 3.1 shows the apparatus used
Fig. 3.1
A student has a selection of rubber bands of different widths. He is investigating the extension produced by adding loads. Fig. 4.1 shows the set-up used
In addition to the apparatus shown in Fig. 4.1, the following apparatus is available to the student:
A metre rule
A selection of different rubber bands
A selection of loads
Plan an experiment to investigate how strips of rubber of different widths stretch when loaded
You should
â€¢ explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation
â€¢ state the key variables that you would control
â€¢ draw a table, or tables, with column headings to show how you would display your readings (You are not required to enter any readings in the table.)
â€¢ explain briefly how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion
